<html><body><div><div id="story-detail" class="story_detail2293932 headlessuser hldAlpha" data-guid="2293932"><p>Three persons of Punjab origin have been charged by the Surrey Police in British Columbia (Canada) in connection with an extortion-related shooting incident in the Crescent Beach neighbourhood on Sunday.</p><p></p><p>The police identified the accused as Harjot Singh (21), Taranveer Singh (19) and Dayajeet Singh Billing (21). They were arrested shortly after officers received reports of gunshots and a small fire outside a residence near Crescent Road and 132 Street around 3.50 am (Canada time).</p><p></p><p>According to the police, officers from the specialised project assurance unit were already patrolling the area due to a spike in extortion-related violence. The suspects were located near 28 Avenue and 140 Street after they allegedly abandoned a vehicle, fled on foot and later entered a rideshare vehicle.</p><p></p><p>Each of them has been charged with discharging a firearm, an offence under Section 244(2)(1)(a) of the Criminal Code of Canada. All three remain in custody and have been remanded until February 5. The Canada Border Services Agency has also been informed in view of the suspects’ immigration status. The police have not released details of their addresses in Punjab.</p><p>The case comes amid a sharp rise in extortion-related crimes in Surrey and across British Columbia’s Lower Mainland. Public Safety Minister Gary Anandasangaree has described the situation as “unacceptable” and announced the deployment of up to 20 additional RCMP officers, along with helicopter support, to strengthen the BC Extortion Task Force and assist local police.</p><p id="inbtw_content_maindiv"></p><p></p><p>Surrey has been particularly affected, with police recording about 35 suspected extortion cases in the first three weeks of January 2026, including at least eight shootings.</p></div></div></body></html>
